description: Several hundred protesters held a peaceful march in Troy on Monday evening to make a stand against the death of George Floyd. There were no issues, except for one man who apparently objected to the protest, and police praised the efforts and sounded their support for the right to assemble. Only the one man was arrested- for driving his vehicle into a participant.
text:
Several hundred protesters held a peaceful march in Troy on Monday evening to
make a stand against the death of George Floyd.

There were no issues, except for one man who apparently objected to the
protest, and police praised the efforts and sounded their support for the
right to assemble.

Only the one man was arrested - for driving his vehicle into a participant.

"We've arrested a 68-year-old male from Troy for felonious assault for
intentionally striking a protester with his car in northbound Coolidge at Big
Beaver," police said. "The victim has no apparent injuries."

Troy police on Twitter and Facebook expressed thanks to and support for the
protesters, saying they appreciated the peaceful efforts.

"Shout out to the Black Alliance Movement Network for organizing a peaceful
and positive event today," police said on Facebook. "Excellent leadership was
displayed by the young people that put this together.

"We appreciate the peaceful protest that has taken place in Troy tonight. We
are inspired by so many young people speaking out against injustice."

Showdown: Law-and-order president versus protesters

The Somerset Collection at Big Beaver Road and Coolidge Highway was closed all
day Monday.

"Given recent events at shopping destinations across the country, coupled with
the company-wide closures of many of our retailers, Somerset Collection is
taking the necessary safety precautions for everyone involved, which includes
closing our center today," said Peter Van Dyke, Somerset spokesman, in a
statement.

"Somerset Collection values and supports freedom of speech and peaceful
protest."

Photos from protest in Troy

Troy Mayor Ethan Baker said before the protest that the Troy Police Department
was well prepared and coordinated efforts with Oakland County authorities, the
Michigan State Police and Somerset Collection management.

The protest, in response to the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis after a
police officer pressed his knee into Floyd's neck, was organized by Black
Lives Matter and By Any Means Necessary, according to fliers announcing the
event.

It started at 5 p.m. at Athens High School; participants marched along Big
Beaver to the police station.

Somerset had just reopened Friday after being shuttered for months because of
the coronavirus pandemic.

Troy police posted on social media at about 6 p.m. that motorists should
expect intermittent closures for the next hour on Big Beaver from Coolidge to
Livernois to allow protesters to walk safely in the road.

"The Troy PD supports the right to peaceful protest and decries injustice. We
are here for you and with you," the police department said on social media.

Protests around the country since Floyd's May 25 death have been marked in
many cases by arrests, violence and destruction of buildings and property.

Large crowds gathered in Detroit over the past four nights, with police
reporting arrests of demonstrators who allegedly hurled items at officers.

About 100 people protested peacefully in Royal Oak Monday evening.

A small protest was held without incident outside the police station in
Livonia Sunday night. Several stores closed in anticipation of possible
rioting.

RELATED:

Strong words, peaceful behavior mark protest in Royal Oak

Trump slams governors as 'weak,' urges crackdown on protests

title: Protest against George Floyd death held in Troy; Somerset Collection closes
html:
Several hundred protesters held a peaceful march in Troy on Monday evening to make a stand against the death of George Floyd.

There were no issues, except for one man who apparently objected to the protest, and police praised the efforts and sounded their support for the right to assemble.

Only the one man was arrested - for driving his vehicle into a participant.

"We've arrested a 68-year-old male from Troy for felonious assault for intentionally striking a protester with his car in northbound Coolidge at Big Beaver," police said. "The victim has no apparent injuries."

Troy police on Twitter and Facebook expressed thanks to and support for the protesters, saying they appreciated the peaceful efforts.

"Shout out to the Black Alliance Movement Network for organizing a peaceful and positive event today," police said on Facebook. "Excellent leadership was displayed by the young people that put this together.

"We appreciate the peaceful protest that has taken place in Troy tonight. We are inspired by so many young people speaking out against injustice."

Showdown: Law-and-order president versus protesters

The Somerset Collection at Big Beaver Road and Coolidge Highway was closed all day Monday.

"Given recent events at shopping destinations across the country, coupled with the company-wide closures of many of our retailers, Somerset Collection is taking the necessary safety precautions for everyone involved, which includes closing our center today," said Peter Van Dyke, Somerset spokesman, in a statement.

"Somerset Collection values and supports freedom of speech and peaceful protest."

Somerset had just reopened Friday after being shuttered for months because of the coronavirus pandemic.

Protests around the country since Floyd's May 25 death have been marked in many cases by arrests, violence and destruction of buildings and property.

Large crowds gathered in Detroit over the past four nights, with police reporting arrests of demonstrators who allegedly hurled items at officers.
